reviewText: It would be difficult to find two more-contrasting works in the entire string-quartet repertoire. It would be as difficult to envisage two performances that provide such a contrast in quality of playing and recording, although these particular contrasts can be at least partially explained by the 13 years and changes of personnel and venue that separated them, as has been already well described. Schubert's "Death and the Maiden" is a difficult quartet to bring off -------- more so, I would say, than those of his predecessors and successors until we get to Bartok and Shostakovich. In my view, the Hagens did not have the maturity in 1980 to tackle the tantalizing changes in emotional moods and technical styles -------both characterized by vast amplitudes-------- that Schubert demands of his players. Yes, they hit the right notes, and for the most part they captured the rhythmic shifts, but their overall cohesion is suspect, and their tone is distinctly ragged in those passages such as the opening of the 1st movement and the greater part of the last two where they are required to force both pace and volume. The muddy recording quality certainly does not help them. Their most convincing work is accomplished in the 2nd movement that is after all the core of the piece, so they deserve credit for that difficult achievement.The Ravel is a very different matter. It is played with great confidence, and a sensitivity for this idiomatically French composition that one would not expect from a Viennese ensemble. Where necessary, they attack with exuberant vigour, but never lapse into roughness or sacrifice clarity to speed and volume. The slower passages are imbued with full sensitivity to the poetry of Ravel's creation. I have never heard a better performance in any medium.One aspect of the DVD format that cannot be overemphasized is the immediacy of a live performance and the bond with a living audience that the camera is capable of establishing. The backgrounds to these compositions do nothing for the music, and in the absence of an audience the atmosphere throughout is somewhat cold and sterile. This affects Schubert's romanticism much more than Ravel's detached analytical style. Contrast the atmosphere exuded by this disc with that of the Lindsay's Haydn Quartets, the Alban Berg's Beethoven Quartets, and the Chamber Music DVDs from the Verbier Festival ------- I am sure you will agree that the excitement rises by several notches when human beings other than the performers fill the screen and contribute their emotions and responses. A production like the present is more like a half-way step between a CD and a real-life DVD, implying that points should be deducted for this omission.In rating this disc, I must first express my dissatisfaction with the 5-star ratings given by two of the earlier reviewers, whose actual words fail to validate their scores. The always erudite and persuasive J. Scott Morrison describes the performances as "quite satisfactory" and Ghost (whoever he is)  concedes that "the whole thing is good". They must surely know that 5 - stars mean "I love it" and 4 - stars mean "I like it". If they can truly say that they loved something that is only "very satisfactory" or " quite good", how would they rate a product that was "magnificent" or "outstanding"? Could the corresponding emotions be contained within the boundaries of mere "love"? Amazingly, Zarathustra gives more space to his delight that the male players are not bald, and there are only two of them ----- 5 stars for equal opportunity and keeping barbers in business! Caveat lector........
Title: N/A

reviewText: The whole thing is good, although the Schubert was recorded a while ago (like fifteen years back) and sports a few "moments" (ahem) with intonation. But the Ravel is current and simply outstanding, marvellous. I have a pile of recordings of this, sublime imo, piece and used to give the top place to the Melos Quartett, but this one is superior. This is a totally exciting record (at least that's how I feel at the moment).PS. It is also amazing how much the group improved between the two recordings. The second violin is different, but that's not because of it -- they've progressed as musicians and as a group. They are impeccable, unearthly, exact, like a single living entity. I'll cease the hype now, but this DVD is certainly worthwhile.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This coupling of the Schubert `Death and the Maiden' quartet with the Ravel quartet brings together two recordings made by the well-respected Hagen Quartet made under quite different circumstances and with different second violins, the other members of the quartet being members of the Austrian Hagen family.The Schubert was made as a studio recording at the Baroque library in Vorau without an audience in 1987. This is presented in 4:3 aspect. The Ravel was made at a public concert in 2000 at the Mozarteum Hall, Salzburg and is presented in 16:9 aspect. Annette Bik plays 2nd violin in the Schubert and Rainer Schmidt plays in the Ravel. Inevitably the quality of the actual recording is superior in the Ravel which benefits from a richer tonal palette both as image quality and as sound. Both recordings offer DTS surround.As regards the performances, the Hagens deliver the level of technical perfection that one now expects of them. It is a pleasure to listen to string quartet playing that is truly in tune all the time. The style of interpretation is generally dramatic and a wide range of dynamics is employed to achieve this. Control of texture and phrasing is part of their impressive cohesion. It should be noted that the last movement of the Ravel is also played at the faster speed that Ravel later requested. Both this and the finale of the Schubert, also played with drive, are performed with total security regardless of the technical demands made.If both quartets had been presented with the recording quality of the Ravel I would unhesitatingly suggest a full 5 stars for this issue. However, because of the age of the Schubert and the compromised technical limitations of the recording, I feel that a drop of one star is inevitable. It would be marvellous if the Hagens could be re-recorded with the same repertoire with the advantages of modern recording techniques. That would be a winner indeed. One can always dream!............................................Some dialogue from the comments section that may offer further help:I thought that you might like to know that before I buy a recording I now look through all the reviews to see if you have posted one. Your assessments and opinions are invaluable. Thank you. (US review)I particularly like your format of review. They give the prospective purchaser an idea of the style of the playing and relevant comparisons. They are succinct. Keep up the good work! (UK review)I'm sure there are many other serious collectors, besides myself, who wait for your synopsis and opinion before spending their hard-earned money on new releases...Keep up the good work!Thank you  (UK review)............................................
summary: Good performances with differing recording qualities

reviewText: The Hagen Quartet is surely the finest string quartet to come out of Austria since the Berg Quartet. Formed in the early 1980s with four Hagen siblings, second violinist Angelika Hagen dropped out in the late 1980s and was replaced briefly by Annette Bik who was then replaced by the current second violinist, Rainer Schmidt. We see, in this DVD, the quartet in two performances recorded thirteen years apart and with one change of personnel. In 1987 they recorded the 'Death and the Maiden' Quartet of Schubert with Bik, and they recorded the Ravel Quartet in 2000 with Schmidt. It is as if they were two completely different quartets. That may be partly due to the extreme differences between the Schubert and Ravel Quartets. But in the Schubert they play like, dare I say it, a German quartet, and I swear that in the Ravel they sound French. The differences are subtle but real and not entirely due to the change in personnel. But Schmidt is a more refined player than Bik was. And certainly the Quartet have matured in the intervening years between the two recordings. One hears a fineness of tone and dynamics in the Ravel that was not present in the rather less nuanced Schubert. The two performances are recorded in different venues, and that may account for some of the difference in sound.Be all that as it may, both performances are quite satisfying. The 'Death and the Maiden' is recorded in the splendor of the Baroque Library in Vorau, Austria. The ornate gold and polished wood library with its domed ceiling and five-meter-high bookcases filled with leather-bound books is a visual treat. The musical highlight, if I had to pick one, of the Schubert performance is the second movement's fourth variation with its delicate first-violin tracery floating over hushed fragments of the theme in the other instruments. The tarantella of the final movement comes across as a dance of death, surely what Schubert wanted. (One recalls that the 'tarantella' was originally the dance-unto-death of a tarantula-bitten person.)The Ravel Quartet was recorded in the Grosser Saal of the Mozarteum in Salzburg, a much plainer but still gorgeous venue. The Quartet's playing here is a lovely combination of classical clarity and impressionistic suggestion. It is astonishing to remember that Ravel wrote the quartet while still at the Paris Conservatoire but that there is absolutely nothing student-like about it. After the vigorous opening movement, the second movement is played pizzicato (as is the second movement of Debussy's single quartet which Ravel had taken as his inspiration and model). One of its felicities is the occurrence of what I've come to think of as its 'simultaneous hemiola' which consists of the first violin and cello playing in 3/4 (three groups of two notes per measure) while the second violin and viola play in 6/8 (two groups of three notes per measure). It is handled by the Hagens with both delicacy and élan. This is followed by the evocative third movement, Très lent, with its episodic construction and varying tempi. The finale is characterized by its Russian feel (just as the second reminds one of Javanese gamelan music) and its 5/8 meter. As in the third movement, Ravel again uses the main theme of the quartet's opening moments. This is a superb performance by the Hagen Quartet, one of the best I've ever heard.Enthusiastically recommended for the Ravel, only slightly less so for the Schubert.Scott Morrison
summary: The Hagen Quartet Plays Two Very Different Masterpieces
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hagen Quartett - Schubert: String Quartet in D Minor "Death and the Maiden"; Ravel: String Quartet in F MajorHave you ever seen a DVD of a string quartet that is not composed of four balding old men looking extremely grave and serious? I didn't think so. Well, you're in for a shock here. Nor only do we have young men here but two, count 'em, two young women performing in the Schubert quartet! And the performances are vigorous and fun to watch. Excellent performances in interesting locations, a hallmark of Euroarts DVDs.
Title: N/A
